articles.headline: Blackwater Case Highlights Legal Uncertainties
articles.snippet: While clear law exists for the military in war zones, a patchwork of untested laws and practical obstacles all but insulate contractors from accountability.
articles.abstract: While clear law exists for the military in war zones, a patchwork of untested laws and practical obstacles all but insulate contractors from accountability.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Oct. 10 — If a private in the United States military fires on civilians, a clear body of law and a set of procedures exist for the military to use in investigating each incident and deciding if the evidence is sufficient to bring charges.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Paul von Zielbauer

articles.headline: A 6-Hour Strike Against Chrysler
articles.snippet: The walkout appears to have been a way for union leaders and company managers to prove they got the best deal they could at a time of deep troubles.
articles.abstract: The walkout appears to have been a way for union leaders and company managers to prove they got the best deal they could at a time of deep troubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Oct. 11 — A new expression is making the rounds here in the nation’s automotive capital: “Hollywood strike,” as in, “just for show.”

articles.headline: Boeing Is Delaying Delivery of Its 787
articles.snippet: The announcement is a blow to a program that had been seen as the most successful in commercial aviation — a perfect blend of technology, marketing and production line innovations.
articles.abstract: The announcement is a blow to a program that had been seen as the most successful in commercial aviation — a perfect blend of technology, marketing and production line innovations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Boeing Company’s announcement yesterday that it would delay initial deliveries of the 787 Dreamliner by six months is a blow to a program that had been seen as the most successful in commercial aviation — a seemingly perfect blend of new technology, marketing and production line innovations.

articles.headline: (Mostly) Good Things in a Small Package
articles.snippet: Palm creates a new smartphone by shaving a few doodads off the Treo.
articles.abstract: Palm creates a new smartphone by shaving a few doodads off the Treo.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes the tiniest adjustment can make a huge difference. A tenth of a grade-point average could get you into Princeton. A bid $1 higher could win on eBay. And a half-step toward the cliff edge could — well, you know.

articles.headline: Stock Sales by Chief of Lender Questioned
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. has been asked to investigate stock sales by Angelo R. Mozilo, Countrywide’s chief executive, before its shares plummeted amid the deepening mortgage crisis.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. has been asked to investigate stock sales by Angelo R. Mozilo, Countrywide’s chief executive, before its shares plummeted amid the deepening mortgage crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has been asked to investigate stock sales made by Angelo R. Mozilo, chief executive of the mortgage lender Countrywide Financial, in the months before its shares plummeted amid the deepening mortgage crisis.

articles.headline: Boom Times for Dentists, but Not for Teeth
articles.snippet: With dentists’ fees rising and millions lacking dental insurance, more people are leaving cavities untreated.
articles.abstract: With dentists’ fees rising and millions lacking dental insurance, more people are leaving cavities untreated.
articles.lead_paragraph: For American dentists, times have never been better.

articles.headline: Safe Food for Japan
articles.snippet: Washington has begun to study Japan’s tough system for ensuring the quality and safety of Chinese imports, particularly food.
articles.abstract: Washington has begun to study Japan’s tough system for ensuring the quality and safety of Chinese imports, particularly food.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Oct. 10 — With Americans growing increasingly concerned about the safety of Chinese products, Washington has begun looking for solutions in Japan.
